speaker: All
text_entry: ACT II

speaker: All
text_entry: SCENE I. Ely House.

speaker: All
text_entry: Enter JOHN OF GAUNT sick, with the DUKE OF YORK, and c

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Will the king come, that I may breathe my last

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: In wholesome counsel to his unstaid youth?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Vex not yourself, nor strive not with your breath;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: For all in vain comes counsel to his ear.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: O, but they say the tongues of dying men

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Enforce attention like deep harmony:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Where words are scarce, they are seldom spent in vain,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: For they breathe truth that breathe their words in pain.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: He that no more must say is listen'd more

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Than they whom youth and ease have taught to glose;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: More are men's ends mark'd than their lives before:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: The setting sun, and music at the close,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: As the last taste of sweets, is sweetest last,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Writ in remembrance more than things long past:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Though Richard my life's counsel would not hear,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: My death's sad tale may yet undeaf his ear.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: No; it is stopp'd with other flattering sounds,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: As praises, of whose taste the wise are fond,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Lascivious metres, to whose venom sound

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: The open ear of youth doth always listen;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Report of fashions in proud Italy,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Whose manners still our tardy apish nation

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Limps after in base imitation.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Where doth the world thrust forth a vanity--

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: So it be new, there's no respect how vile--

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: That is not quickly buzzed into his ears?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Then all too late comes counsel to be heard,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Where will doth mutiny with wit's regard.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Direct not him whose way himself will choose:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: 'Tis breath thou lack'st, and that breath wilt thou lose.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Methinks I am a prophet new inspired

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: And thus expiring do foretell of him:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: His rash fierce blaze of riot cannot last,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: For violent fires soon burn out themselves;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Small showers last long, but sudden storms are short;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: He tires betimes that spurs too fast betimes;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: With eager feeding food doth choke the feeder:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Light vanity, insatiate cormorant,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Consuming means, soon preys upon itself.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: This royal throne of kings, this scepter'd isle,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: This earth of majesty, this seat of Mars,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: This other Eden, demi-paradise,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: This fortress built by Nature for herself

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Against infection and the hand of war,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: This happy breed of men, this little world,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: This precious stone set in the silver sea,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Which serves it in the office of a wall,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Or as a moat defensive to a house,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Against the envy of less happier lands,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: This blessed plot, this earth, this realm, this England,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: This nurse, this teeming womb of royal kings,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Fear'd by their breed and famous by their birth,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Renowned for their deeds as far from home,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: For Christian service and true chivalry,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: As is the sepulchre in stubborn Jewry,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Of the world's ransom, blessed Mary's Son,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: This land of such dear souls, this dear dear land,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Dear for her reputation through the world,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Is now leased out, I die pronouncing it,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Like to a tenement or pelting farm:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: England, bound in with the triumphant sea

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Whose rocky shore beats back the envious siege

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Of watery Neptune, is now bound in with shame,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: With inky blots and rotten parchment bonds:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: That England, that was wont to conquer others,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Hath made a shameful conquest of itself.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Ah, would the scandal vanish with my life,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: How happy then were my ensuing death!

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Enter KING RICHARD II and QUEEN, DUKE OF AUMERLE,  BUSHY, GREEN, BAGOT, LORD ROSS, and LORD WILLOUGHBY

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: The king is come: deal mildly with his youth;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: For young hot colts being raged do rage the more.

speaker: QUEEN
text_entry: How fares our noble uncle, Lancaster?

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What comfort, man? how is't with aged Gaunt?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: O how that name befits my composition!

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Old Gaunt indeed, and gaunt in being old:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Within me grief hath kept a tedious fast;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: And who abstains from meat that is not gaunt?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: For sleeping England long time have I watch'd;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Watching breeds leanness, leanness is all gaunt:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: The pleasure that some fathers feed upon,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Is my strict fast; I mean, my children's looks;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: And therein fasting, hast thou made me gaunt:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Gaunt am I for the grave, gaunt as a grave,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Whose hollow womb inherits nought but bones.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Can sick men play so nicely with their names?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: No, misery makes sport to mock itself:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Since thou dost seek to kill my name in me,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: I mock my name, great king, to flatter thee.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Should dying men flatter with those that live?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: No, no, men living flatter those that die.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Thou, now a-dying, say'st thou flatterest me.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: O, no! thou diest, though I the sicker be.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: I am in health, I breathe, and see thee ill.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Now He that made me knows I see thee ill;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Ill in myself to see, and in thee seeing ill.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Thy death-bed is no lesser than thy land

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Wherein thou liest in reputation sick;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: And thou, too careless patient as thou art,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Commit'st thy anointed body to the cure

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Of those physicians that first wounded thee:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: A thousand flatterers sit within thy crown,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Whose compass is no bigger than thy head;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: And yet, incaged in so small a verge,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: The waste is no whit lesser than thy land.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: O, had thy grandsire with a prophet's eye

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Seen how his son's son should destroy his sons,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: From forth thy reach he would have laid thy shame,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Deposing thee before thou wert possess'd,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Which art possess'd now to depose thyself.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Why, cousin, wert thou regent of the world,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: It were a shame to let this land by lease;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: But for thy world enjoying but this land,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Is it not more than shame to shame it so?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Landlord of England art thou now, not king:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Thy state of law is bondslave to the law; And thou--

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: A lunatic lean-witted fool,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Presuming on an ague's privilege,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Darest with thy frozen admonition

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Make pale our cheek, chasing the royal blood

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: With fury from his native residence.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Now, by my seat's right royal majesty,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Wert thou not brother to great Edward's son,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: This tongue that runs so roundly in thy head

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Should run thy head from thy unreverent shoulders.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: O, spare me not, my brother Edward's son,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: For that I was his father Edward's son;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: That blood already, like the pelican,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Hast thou tapp'd out and drunkenly caroused:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: My brother Gloucester, plain well-meaning soul,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Whom fair befal in heaven 'mongst happy souls!

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: May be a precedent and witness good

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: That thou respect'st not spilling Edward's blood:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Join with the present sickness that I have;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: And thy unkindness be like crooked age,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: To crop at once a too long wither'd flower.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Live in thy shame, but die not shame with thee!

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: These words hereafter thy tormentors be!

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Convey me to my bed, then to my grave:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Love they to live that love and honour have.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Exit, borne off by his Attendants

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And let them die that age and sullens have;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For both hast thou, and both become the grave.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I do beseech your majesty, impute his words

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: To wayward sickliness and age in him:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: He loves you, on my life, and holds you dear

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: As Harry Duke of Hereford, were he here.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Right, you say true: as Hereford's love, so his;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: As theirs, so mine; and all be as it is.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Enter NORTHUMBERLAND

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: My liege, old Gaunt commends him to your majesty.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: What says he?

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Nay, nothing; all is said

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: His tongue is now a stringless instrument;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Words, life and all, old Lancaster hath spent.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Be York the next that must be bankrupt so!

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Though death be poor, it ends a mortal woe.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The ripest fruit first falls, and so doth he;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: His time is spent, our pilgrimage must be.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: So much for that. Now for our Irish wars:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We must supplant those rough rug-headed kerns,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Which live like venom where no venom else

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: But only they have privilege to live.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And for these great affairs do ask some charge,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Towards our assistance we do seize to us

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: The plate, corn, revenues and moveables,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Whereof our uncle Gaunt did stand possess'd.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: How long shall I be patient? ah, how long

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Shall tender duty make me suffer wrong?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Not Gloucester's death, nor Hereford's banishment

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Not Gaunt's rebukes, nor England's private wrongs,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Nor the prevention of poor Bolingbroke

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: About his marriage, nor my own disgrace,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Have ever made me sour my patient cheek,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Or bend one wrinkle on my sovereign's face.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I am the last of noble Edward's sons,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Of whom thy father, Prince of Wales, was first:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: In war was never lion raged more fierce,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: In peace was never gentle lamb more mild,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Than was that young and princely gentleman.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: His face thou hast, for even so look'd he,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Accomplish'd with the number of thy hours;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But when he frown'd, it was against the French

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And not against his friends; his noble hand

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Did will what he did spend and spent not that

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Which his triumphant father's hand had won;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: His hands were guilty of no kindred blood,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But bloody with the enemies of his kin.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: O Richard! York is too far gone with grief,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Or else he never would compare between.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Why, uncle, what's the matter?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: O my liege,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Pardon me, if you please; if n ot, I, pleased

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Not to be pardon'd, am content withal.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Seek you to seize and gripe into your hands

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: The royalties and rights of banish'd Hereford?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Is not Gaunt dead, and doth not Hereford live?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Was not Gaunt just, and is not Harry true?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Did not the one deserve to have an heir?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Is not his heir a well-deserving son?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Take Hereford's rights away, and take from Time

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: His charters and his customary rights;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Let not to-morrow then ensue to-day;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Be not thyself; for how art thou a king

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But by fair sequence and succession?

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Now, afore God--God forbid I say true!--

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: If you do wrongfully seize Hereford's rights,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Call in the letters patent that he hath

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: By his attorneys-general to sue

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: His livery, and deny his offer'd homage,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: You pluck a thousand dangers on your head,

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: You lose a thousand well-disposed hearts

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: And prick my tender patience, to those thoughts

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Which honour and allegiance cannot think.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Think what you will, we seize into our hands

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: His plate, his goods, his money and his lands.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: I'll not be by the while: my liege, farewell:

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: What will ensue hereof, there's none can tell;

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: But by bad courses may be understood

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: That their events can never fall out good.

speaker: DUKE OF YORK
text_entry: Exit

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Go, Bushy, to the Earl of Wiltshire straight:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Bid him repair to us to Ely House

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: To see this business. To-morrow next

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: We will for Ireland; and 'tis time, I trow:

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: And we create, in absence of ourself,

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Our uncle York lord governor of England;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: For he is just and always loved us well.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Come on, our queen: to-morrow must we part;

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Be merry, for our time of stay is short

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Flourish. Exeunt KING RICHARD II, QUEEN, DUKE OF AUMERLE, BUSHY, GREEN, and BAGOT

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Well, lords, the Duke of Lancaster is dead.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: And living too; for now his son is duke.

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: Barely in title, not in revenue.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Richly in both, if justice had her right.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: My heart is great; but it must break with silence,

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: Ere't be disburden'd with a liberal tongue.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Nay, speak thy mind; and let him ne'er speak more

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: That speaks thy words again to do thee harm!

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: Tends that thou wouldst speak to the Duke of Hereford?

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: If it be so, out with it boldly, man;

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: Quick is mine ear to hear of good towards him.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: No good at all that I can do for him;

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: Unless you call it good to pity him,

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: Bereft and gelded of his patrimony.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Now, afore God, 'tis shame such wrongs are borne

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: In him, a royal prince, and many moe

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Of noble blood in this declining land.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The king is not himself, but basely led

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: By flatterers; and what they will inform,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Merely in hate, 'gainst any of us all,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: That will the king severely prosecute

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: 'Gainst us, our lives, our children, and our heirs.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: The commons hath he pill'd with grievous taxes,

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: And quite lost their hearts: the nobles hath he fined

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: For ancient quarrels, and quite lost their hearts.

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: And daily new exactions are devised,

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: As blanks, benevolences, and I wot not what:

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: But what, o' God's name, doth become of this?

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Wars have not wasted it, for warr'd he hath not,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: But basely yielded upon compromise

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: That which his noble ancestors achieved with blows:

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: More hath he spent in peace than they in wars.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: The Earl of Wiltshire hath the realm in farm.

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: The king's grown bankrupt, like a broken man.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Reproach and dissolution hangeth over him.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: He hath not money for these Irish wars,

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: His burthenous taxations notwithstanding,

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: But by the robbing of the banish'd duke.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: His noble kinsman: most degenerate king!

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: But, lords, we hear this fearful tempest sing,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Yet see no shelter to avoid the storm;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: We see the wind sit sore upon our sails,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And yet we strike not, but securely perish.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: We see the very wreck that we must suffer;

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: And unavoided is the danger now,

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: For suffering so the causes of our wreck.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Not so; even through the hollow eyes of death

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: I spy life peering; but I dare not say

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: How near the tidings of our comfort is.

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: Nay, let us share thy thoughts, as thou dost ours.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: Be confident to speak, Northumberland:

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: We three are but thyself; and, speaking so,

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: Thy words are but as thoughts; therefore, be bold.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Then thus: I have from Port le Blanc, a bay

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: In Brittany, received intelligence

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: That Harry Duke of Hereford, Rainold Lord Cobham,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: That late broke from the Duke of Exeter,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: His brother, Archbishop late of Canterbury,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Sir Thomas Erpingham, Sir John Ramston,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Sir John Norbery, Sir Robert Waterton and Francis Quoint,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: All these well furnish'd by the Duke of Bretagne

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: With eight tall ships, three thousand men of war,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Are making hither with all due expedience

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And shortly mean to touch our northern shore:

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Perhaps they had ere this, but that they stay

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: The first departing of the king for Ireland.

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: If then we shall shake off our slavish yoke,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Imp out our drooping country's broken wing,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Redeem from broking pawn the blemish'd crown,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Wipe off the dust that hides our sceptre's gilt

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: And make high majesty look like itself,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Away with me in post to Ravenspurgh;

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: But if you faint, as fearing to do so,

speaker: NORTHUMBERLAND
text_entry: Stay and be secret, and myself will go.

speaker: LORD ROSS
text_entry: To horse, to horse! urge doubts to them that fear.

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: Hold out my horse, and I will first be there.

speaker: LORD WILLOUGHBY
text_entry: Exeunt
